turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Go to your room.  And you...I don't suppose your father gave you permission to pierce your ears, did he?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Not exactly.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well just don't shave your legs...he'll never let you visit us again if I send you home hairless and full of holes.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Shelly's sick...I have to get to the bottom of this whole thing and get back there.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: She'll be all right baby.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Yeah...right, it's pointless to worry.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Bye Aunt Rose.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Bye Niece, Vada.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: So what's wrong?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Nothing, nothing at all.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: I mean...with your car.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Oh, ahh, oil change, I...ehh...I just drove in from Chicago and uhh...nice hair.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I was commenting on your hair.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, are you a hairdresser?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'm a pediatric cardiologist.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, you mean you...fix the hearts...of little babies?

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Mostly...little babies, but...not exclusively.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: ...It's all in the hands really. You know you have nice hands, you operate?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Yes, I do.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: ...so I guess I'll always...teach...you know...'cause it makes a good relief from the operating-room, I feel I have an obligation...

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Ahh, Dr. Helburn, why don't you come in tomorrow-morning at eight o'clock, that's when we open, we'll get you started.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'll be here.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well maybe for you.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Something wrong?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well let's just say you're lucky you deal with children who are under anesthesia.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Well, even without anesthesia I always tell my patients to...eh... to relax.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh no, I, I...eh...I couldn't.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: You couldn't?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Well I'm sort of involved.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Sort of?

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Let's just say I...eh...I'm involved.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Where I come from, involvement...generally calls for a substantial piece of jewelry.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, well, I don't wear a lot of jewelry.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: All right, so you don't like jewelry but...eh...you do like...eh...good music. Liszt, one of my favorites.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Lizt was my parents' favorite, they were Hungarian.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Hungarian. Famous for their beautiful music...and beautiful women.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: Ahh, why don't I come in first thing in the morning and you can check out that left blinker for me.

turns.speaker: ROSE
turns.text: Oh, sure okay.

turns.speaker: SAM
turns.text: I'll see you then...I look forward to it.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Assuming the baby's a "Supremes" fan.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I bet your mom sang to you.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: They're enormous, I know.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Is there milk in them already?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: No, the milk comes when the baby comes.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: When did you umm, I mean umm...

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Oh, I was a very late developer, they used to call me "Shelly Two Backs". All my friends had real bra's, not like the training ones I had.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Why do they call them training bra's? It's not like learning to ride a bike.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I know, I guess it's just sort of preparing you for the rest of your life. It's not easy being a woman.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: You're telling me.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Then Grammoo said on Christmas Eve, there was this sickening smell permeating the entire house.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Oh no.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Mmmmmm. Root beer float that sounds good.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Did she mention any contests that she won? I mean she must have had some awards, she was so talented and all.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: What's this? December 8th, 1958?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I don't know, Dad doesn't either.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Well, it must mean something. She was obviously very sentimental.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: This is one of my favorite things, her passport.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Oh Vada she's so beautiful.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Margaret's my middle name, but everybody called her Maggie. Los Angeles, have you ever been there?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: No. You know they say, that it never rains, that you can barbecue on Christmas day...instead of riding your bike, you just surf over to your friends house. Oh, and the place is just crawling with celebrities. I know someone who saw Walter Matthau picking up his dry-cleaning.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Is that why Uncle Phil moved there?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Uncle Phil just needed a change, a little adventure.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I wonder why she got a passport if she never went anywhere.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Well you've gotta be prepared.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I'm definitely traveling some day.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Why not now?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: How would you like to go visit your Uncle Phil in Los Angeles...next week during your spring vacation, you could do research on your mom.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: But what about you and the baby? You need me.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Oh, but I'm not due to have the baby for another six weeks or so.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Yeah, it would be kinda great.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: It would be fantastic.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: But Dad'll never go for it.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: You leave your father to me.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Shelly?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Hey! Oh look.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: He's so tiny.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I know, look at his little hands.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Did it hurt a lot?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: You have no idea.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Let me hold him.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: O.K.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Who didn't? She could play basketball like Jerry West, she danced like Sid Cherice, then she'd look at you with those big blue eyes, forget about it. I asked her out a couple of times but she always said no.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Beidermeyer?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Beidermeyer that's it, what a mad man.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: He's a great poet.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: He is?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Do you know him?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: Everybody did, walk along Citrus between Fountain and Sunset any afternoon.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: He'll remember my mother for sure.  STANLEY It was a big class Vada and...but...well of course he'll remember, who could forget Maggie?

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: No it doesn't but... I...I wish it did.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Well, thanks for your help Mr. Rosenfeld and I'm sorry my mother wouldn't go out with you, I'm sure she would have had a really great time.

turns.speaker: STANLEY
turns.text: I would have tried to show her a good time. I promised her when she left that I would never forget her and I never did. Stanley Rosenfeld does not forget.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: This is the street he walks down every day. When he needs inspiration...

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Arthur!!

turns.speaker: ARTHUR
turns.text: Vada!!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I beat Thomas J in monopoly yesterday.

turns.speaker: ARTHUR
turns.text: Good for you baby.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Once you put the hotels on board walk and Park Place he puts a shoe in your way.

turns.speaker: ARTHUR
turns.text: I like to buy off all the railroads.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Wanna play?

turns.speaker: ARTHUR
turns.text: No, I gotta go to the cemetery, keep your head up. Don't look at the ball, look at me.

turns.speaker: BOY#2
turns.text: Yeah, to play with his DOLLS.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Leave him alone! Come on, let's go.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Hey, you didn't pay me!

turns.speaker: BOY#2
turns.text: How do I know you were gonna show us one?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: You're such a baby.

turns.speaker: BOY#2
turns.text: All right, here.

turns.speaker: BOY#2
turns.text: Of what??

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Well, sometimes when we get 'em, they're not completely dead, you know, like when they cut a chickens head off and it still runs around crazy.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Uhh, it's nice to meet ya. Uhh, we got burgers and hot dogs here if you'd care to join us?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Can't stay, I'm just here because my wife.....

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Danny?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: WHAT?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Okay, I know you've suffered a terrible loss, and there's really nothing anyone can do to comfort you, but I urge you to focus on the times you had with the camper, the trips you took, the sights you saw, those days are gone now, but they'll live on in your heart forever.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: This guy bonking you?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Oh.. Oh.. Oh no?? Oh?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: It's her home! It's where she lives!!

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Oh really, okay fine look, go cook,  Gimme the goddam keys.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: What am I doing here????? What am I doing here?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Hi Ralph. Oh Danny, how'd you find me here?

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: You told everybody where you were going, I'm here for the motor home.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I've been living in it for over a year, the camper is mine.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Excuse me, MUTUAL ASSET, that's what the lawyer said, it's supposed to be "OUR MUTUAL ASSET", not "Shelly's recreational vehicle". Gimme the keys.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Keep your voice down!

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: The boss is watching us...

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: I'm impressed.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: God I guess i'll have to introduce you now.

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Yeah, all right...

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: This is Harry, Phil, Grammoo and Vada Sultenfuss...

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: Vada Sultenfuss?? Tough break.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Ex...ex, ex...

turns.speaker: DANNY
turns.text: My __EX__ wife seems to have ripped off my camper.

turns.speaker: DR WELTY
turns.text: You are perfectly healthy.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: That can't be, I have all the classic symptoms.

turns.speaker: DR WELTY
turns.text: Sweetheart, did they bring Mr. Layton to your house today?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DR WELTY
turns.text: Vada you've gotta stop this, there's absolutely nothing wrong with you!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Can't you see it?

turns.speaker: DR WELTY
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: It's there.

turns.speaker: DR WELTY
turns.text: Vada there is no chicken bone stuck in your throat.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Dr. Welty!!!? Dr. Welty??

turns.speaker: DR WELTY
turns.text: Vada, what's wrong sweetheart?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I can't breathe, I'm suffocating.

turns.speaker: DR WELTY
turns.text: Oh, wait relax now, let me look, let me look, come up here and we'll have a look.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: It hurts, it hurts so bad, make it stop.

turns.speaker: DR WELTY
turns.text: What Hurts Vada?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: The bee stings! I can't breathe!

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: It's still available I hope?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I think it's still available.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I'm a licensed cosmetologist, I worked for two years, at the "Dino Raphael" Salon, all my customers cried when I told them I was leaving.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Uhh, Miss devoto...

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I have a wonderful disposition, I put people right at ease.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Uhh, Miss devoto, these people are already at ease. This is not a Beauty Parlor, it's a Funeral Parlor.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: They're dead?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yes they are.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Stiffs??

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Deceased.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: The add just said "Makeup Artist"

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Excuse me, what about the job?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Pardon?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I need the job.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, You still want it? Even though uhh...

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Ohh, oh sure it's no big deal, you see all my former clients will eventually die, and all your clients used to be alive, so they have something in common.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You'd be doing hair and makeup and answering the phone.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Okay Mr. Sultenfuss, you got a deal.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Great, you can start right away. Call me Harry. Now, umm, is this what you'd normally wear for work? Don't get me wrong, I like it, very much, but the....

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I promise i'll take good care of these people, they deserve it, they're dead, all they've got left is their looks.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Uh huh?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Could you take a look at Mrs. Porter?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: You don't like it?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: This was the Reverend Porter's wife, you have her looking like a two dollar hooker.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I think she looks nice! Her lips are very thin so I used the gloss to give them a more sensual quality, and her eyes just needed a little definition, and her hair, I'm sorry, nobody wears this hairdo anymore in 1972.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: She did. This photo was taken a month ago at the church food drive.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I just wanted to get past this "old school Marm" image.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: That wasn't an image. She WAS an old school Marm.  Fix it.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Harry?  I was just wondering, if there is anything wrong with Vada.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: What do you mean??

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Well the other night at dinner...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh that, she just likes to play.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I don't think so, I think she's confused about death.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: She was raised in a funeral home, she knows a thing or two about it.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Harry, I really think she.....

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: She's a perfectly happy eleven year old girl, look, don't give me any advice about my daughter, okay?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Can not do without, Harry's wild about me.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Excuse me Harry, I'm sorry, I just wanna let you know that the flowers were delivered. And the room's all set up.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Thanks, listen I wanna apologize for the other day downstairs, about Vada, I was a little harsh.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I shouldn't stick my nose in other people's business. It's just that I like Vada, very much.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: After my wife died, Grammoo moved in here to help take care of Vada. They were very close, but lately as her mind's been wandering more and more, Vada's been acting kinda crazy. I'm sure she'll snap out of it though.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I'm sure she will.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh Hi, what can I do for you?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Nothing, I was just wondering what you were doing.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, I'm just typing up a funeral notice, you know when someone dies people want it in the paper usually, it's a service we provide for the family.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Oh right, right, . Bader Lorenzo Died June 22 1972 Devoted husband to Nicolette. Cherished father of Babritzio and Heidi, In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the holy names society.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I wrote that.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: No kidding?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Oh it's good, "In lieu of" I love that word lieu.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I prefer it to "instead", it has more dignity.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: In lieu... "instead".... No contest.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: It's no big deal.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: You have to learn how to take a complement.  Movies, movies, ahhhh, "Love Story" at the drive in, I cried my eyes out, did you see it?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I haven't been to the movies in AGES.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I love going to movies, especially at the drive in. I don't think there's anything more romantic than going to the drive in.  I'll let you get back to work.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I do enjoy playing bingo, if you'd like to join me for a game tomorrow night at church you're welcome to.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Does it make it easier to win?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: No. Just, more activity.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I just had a terrible thought Harry.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I'm gonna be putting makeup on some of these people very soon.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Why d'you think these seats were empty.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Oh, I'm just not lucky Harry.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Look, it's not always luck, I mean, depending upon the placement of the numbers, a guy with 10 cards could win just as easily as a guy with 100.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Kinda like men.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, how do you mean?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: You can be in a room with 100 men, and not like any of them, or you can be in a room with just one man, and he's exactly the one you want.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I had a good time tonight.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I haven't had a bingo partner in ages.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Would you like to come in and see my house? Just for a minute.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Okay, sure.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Home sweet home.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: It's nice.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I did it myself. I read a magazine article about how to maximize small spaces.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Well it certainly looks bigger that it seems.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: You can look in the bathroom if you want. People are always curious about that, like what happens when you flush.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Are you mad at me?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: No, why?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I don't know, tonight you just seemed a little cool, not opening car doors and...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, that was Phil, trying to give me advice on dating 70's women. Look I'm so out of touch, I haven't dated women in ages, not since my wife died.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: What happened to her?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Ahh, complications during child birth, she died two days after Vada was born.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Did she ever see Vada?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I brought the baby into the room a couple of times, she opened her eyes, yeah, yeah I think she saw Vada. It was.....

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Dance with me?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Here?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: This is where we are.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Is there enough room?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I haven't danced in.....

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: In ages, I know, me neither.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Rock?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: See, you're not that out of touch.  You're good.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: At Widdman High I was considered a pretty hot date, I did a killer frugue.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: What are you wearing?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Old Spice, Phil says it's a timeless classic.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Do you want to?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Want to what?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Kiss me.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I ahh, better go.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: It's only eight o'clock.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Goodnight Shelly.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Goodnight.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'm tired of bingo, maybe we should try that drive in of yours.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Goodnight.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'm just picking some things up for the barbecue.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Yeah, me too, mind if I tag along?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Not at all. Lot of potatoes!

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: It's for Shelly's famous potato salad.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'm looking forward to that.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: You know this is gonna be my first 4th of July picnic in a long time.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: How's it going chef?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Rub a dub dub, thanks for the grub, yay God.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'll second that.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Shelly?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Honestly Harry, he got the mustang, I promise.....

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Danny that's a real _bonehead_ thing to say!

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Look, you're not gonna take Shelly's camper.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Well, you were pretty great!

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Is it really your camper?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Can we see it from the back yard?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: You can get the general idea...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yep, there they are... They always look the same every year...

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Pointing upwards Look...

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Did you ahh, love him?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I would never marry anybody I didn't love.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Watch you don't knock out a fish.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Perfect.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I don't know which ball's mine.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Open your eyes, she's eleven years old! Her only friend in the world is dead.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I know that, but what do you want from me?

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: Stop hiding Harry, you run Harry. When I first came here, the idea of working with dead people, didn't exactly thrill me, but when I saw a family lived here, I thought, "if I'm living without a family, at least I can work with one, and maybe once in a while i'll be invited in for supper."

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yeah, and when those suppers are disrupted because there's a car crash, or there's a fire, or a little boy steps on a beehive.

turns.speaker: SHELLY
turns.text: I'm not asking you to stop feeling for those people. But life isn't just death Harry, don't ignore the living, especially your daughter.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I was born jaundiced. Once I sat on a toilet seat at a Truck stop and caught hemorrhoids. And i've learned to live with this chicken Bone that's been lodged in my throat for the past three years, so I knew Dad would be devastated when he learned of my latest affliction.  Dad, I don't wanna upset you, but my left breast is developing at a significantly faster rate than my right. It can only mean one thing.  Cancer.  I'm dying.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: O.K. Sweetie, hand me the mayonnaise out of the fridge.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Ahem.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Vada, just put 'em on the stool.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Daddy guess what I beat Thomas J in monopoly yesterday.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Ya, that rack holds six ties.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Vada, we're trying to work here.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Cruella deville stole all the puppies, she was gonna make a fur out of 'em!

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Hand me the canula.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: VADA!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Dad?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'm embalming my high school teacher, don't sing.  All right Arthur, just a slide of the needle.....

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Daddy, how come that coffin's so small?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: They come in all sizes honey, just like shoes.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Is it for a child?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Of course not.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Then who's it for?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Daddy, can I have thirty five dollars?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: That's a lot of money for a little girl.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: It's for school, for summer writing class.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Any more soda left?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Shelly thinks I'd be a good writer.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Last month you wanted to play the violin. Then you wanted to be a ventriloquist.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Dad?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I love this guy!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Dad??

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: The money?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Ahh, maybe next summer.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Goodnight Vada.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Dad, why are you dressed up to go to bingo?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Ahh, I just wanna look nice.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: You never cared before.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Well Shelly's coming over, we're gonna go together.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: She likes to play bingo.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Can I go too?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Naah, I think you'd better stay here and keep Grammoo company.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: HEY, OUCH, damn it!! Vada, watch what you're doing.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Dad, didn't you say you needed prunes REAL bad?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Ahh, Vada, just put anything you want in the cart, anything at all.  I don't know what's gotten into her today.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Are they ready yet?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: No, sweetie, not yet.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Soon honey, soon.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: When??

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: In a minute, look it's hot, sweetie you'll burn your nose, look out.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Yes..

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Hey guess what? We're going to the carnival tonight, be ready to go in 10 minutes.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I like the freak show.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I know, I know, let's go on the "sit on the bench and rest" ride.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: We're having the wedding sometime near the end of the summer.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Not acknowledging Harry's comment You'll be okay little fish.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I fall asleep at the wheel.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I'll ride on the bumper cars with you!

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Hi Vada.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: What are you doing.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Feeding my fish.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Is that the fish you won at the carnival?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: He's getting big.  Vada, come here and sit down for a minute.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Vada, something happened to Thomas J last night, he stepped on a beehive.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I told him not to tease those bees. Did he get stung?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Maybe I should go over and yell at him.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: No sweetheart, you can't.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: He was allergic to bees.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: He's okay isn't he?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: There were just too many of 'em.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: He's gone sweetheart. He's gone!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Get away, get away!!

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Did I kill my mother?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: What??

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: The bees killed Thomas J, and I killed my mother.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: No, no.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I found this.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I forgot about that picture, where did you find it?

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: In the garage.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Ahh, that little Chevy was your mothers favorite car.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: What was my mama like?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: She was pretty, and kind, she had your eyes. Oh boy did she love to laugh. Sometimes when you laugh, you sound just like her.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Uh huh. You know what your mother did when she found out she was gonna have you? She came home and painted this whole room pink. She was so sure she was gonna have a little girl.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: Do you miss her?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Yes, I did, very much for a long time, and even now, I get a little sad when I think of a pretty flower or a sunset that your mother would have liked.

turns.speaker: VADA
turns.text: I think every time I see a climbing tree i'll think of Thomas J.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: That's good, memories are good sweetheart. Vada, I'm sorry; I was trying to keep it from you, I just couldn't. You're a good girl, and I want you to be happy; don't be an old grump like me.  Seeya in the morning.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Well well well, what's going on in here?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Nothing, I'm dressing.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Oh, you're dressing, uh huh, Harry Harry Harry Harry, don't you know it's not nice to lie to your big brother?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Oh yes, oh that's great.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: I'm very nervous.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: The last date I had was twenty years ago.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: That's true. Harry Harry sit down, let me fill you in on today's women, since the last time you dated, something happened, "The Sexual Revolution", now before that, you used to have to hold a door open for a woman, pull her chair out, pick up the check, no more no more, you wanna know what else is missing? BRAS!

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh come on.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Harry, I'm serious, trust me Harry this woman's lifting us in, you gotta treat her like every Tom Dick and Harry.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Are you sure about all this?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Did you not tell Vada I'm a womanizer huh?

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: Oh, I'm running late. Shelly'll be here any minute.

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Oh she's picking you up, good you're on the right track.

turns.speaker: HARRY
turns.text: No, she's just driving over here, then we're taking my car. How do I look?

turns.speaker: PHIL
turns.text: Like a Sultenfuss. Go get 'em.
